𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐟𝐚𝐫 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐰𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐚𝐬 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐢𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐋𝐆𝐁𝐓𝐐+ 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲? 👉 1967: Sex between two men over 21 and 'in private' was decriminalized. BUT gay sex remained illegal in Scotland and Northern Ireland until 1982 as well as those serving in the armed forces, 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐬𝐭 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐰𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧'𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐢𝐧 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐥𝐞𝐠𝐢𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐥 𝟐𝟎𝟏𝟎! 👉 1972: The first Pride march was held in London, where 2000 participants supported and contributed. Today, however, this number rises to up to a million, where various Pride events occur throughout the year and across the UK. 👉 1988: Margaret Thatcher introduced Section 28 of the Local Government Act 1988. This banned the 'promotion' of homosexuality by local authorities and in British schools. 👉 1992: The World Health Organization declassified same-sex attraction as a mental illness. 𝐒𝐡𝐨𝐜𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝟑𝟏 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐚𝐠𝐨. 👉 2000: The ban on gay and bisexual people serving in the armed forces was lifted. 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝟐𝟒 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐚𝐠𝐨!! 👉 2002: Same sex couples were given equal rights when it came to adoption. 👉 2004: The Civil Partnership Act passed and The Gender Recognition Act passed. 👉 2013: The Marriage (Same-sex couples) Act was passed, legalizing same-sex marriages. It's clear that we've come a long way, yet the timeline also highlights that progress is an ongoing effort. 𝐈𝐭'𝐬 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐭𝐞 𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲 𝐲𝐞𝐭. 𝐖𝐞'𝐫𝐞 𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐟𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐋𝐆𝐁𝐓𝐐+ 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲. #lgbtqhistorymonth #raiseawareness

Here are the directions issued by the Hon'ble CJI in the Same-Sex Marriage Case. -The Union and State Governments along with the governments of UTs are directed to: i. Make sure there is no discrimination towards queer community. Ii. Make sure that the queer community is not being discriminated against while accessing goods and services which are available to everyone else. iii. To make efforts toward sensitisation of the public about queer identity. iv. Create hotline numbers for the queer community in case of violence or harassment. v. Establish shelter houses for the queer community facing discrimination or violence. vi. Make sure that treatments which aim to change gender of persons are ceased with immediate effect. vii. Make sure that inter-sex children are not forced to undergo operations for their sex. Take extra care if they are incompetent for a valid consent. viii. Make sure no person is forced to undergo hormonal therapy etc. Also recognize the self-identified gender of all persons. #samesexmarriage #supremecourt #india #gender #directions #government

No one left behind: equality, freedom and justice for all! Today is the International Day Against Homophobia, Biphobia, and Transphobia (IDAHOBIT). With equality, freedom and justice in mind, we want to bring attention to the recently announced review of Relationships, Sex and Health Education (RSHE) in the UK. Following years of targeted anti-trans sentiment, the proposed RSHE guidance states simply that "gender identity should not be taught". Pushing trans and nonbinary people from the public eye doesn't change the reality that we exist. Children should not be brought up with a narrow and unrealistic understanding of human diversity, leaving them woefully unprepared for a naturally diverse world. Simply not teaching about gender will not prevent kids from being trans and non-binary, but it will teach those kids to live in enforced silence and shame. We are still feeling the repercussions of Section 28. A repeat of that injustice is being threatened again, now. The gov review of the RSHE statutory guidance consultation is open now and closes 11:59pm on 11 July 2024. Please fill it out - let's oppose the utter inadequacy of this proposed guidance, together (link in our bio). Not one child or young person should be left behind. Equality, freedom, and justice for ALL! #Proud2Be #Trans #Nonbinary #Gay #Bi #IDAHOBIT #IDAHOBIT2024 #LGBT #LGBTQ #LGBTQIA

Key facts: 62 countries have laws that criminalize private, consensual, same-sex sexual activity, mainly for men. Almost half of them are Commonwealth jurisdictions. 12 of them have jurisdictions in which the death penalty is imposed or at least a possibility for private, consensual same-sex sexual activity. At least 6 of these implement the death penalty. 14 countries criminalize the gender identity and expression of transgender people. In many more countries, transgender people are targeted by a range of laws that criminalize same-sex activity and vagrancy, hooliganism, and public order offenses. It is important to note that legality of same-sex sexual acts cannot be read as evidence of a safer living environment for people with diverse sexual orientations or gender identities or expressions. In many of the States where consensual same-sex sexual acts are legal, the social stigmatization of people who are perceived as non-heterosexual or non-cisgender remains alarmingly high. Sources: https://lnkd.in/dPWQZUpt https://lnkd.in/dwdYSBU #LGBTQ+ #DEI #humanrights #sexualrights #safety

“International Day Against Homophobia, Biphobia and Transphobia was created in 2004 to draw attention to the violence and discrimination experienced by lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans and intersex people, all of those with diverse sexual orientations, gender identities or expressions and sex characteristics. May 17 was chosen to commemorate the World Health Organization's decision to declassify homosexuality as a mental disorder, in 1990. It is currently celebrated in more than 130 countries, including 37 where same-sex acts are illegal. This year's theme is "No One Left Behind: Equality, Freedom and Justice for All". The world has just celebrated the 75th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights – a document that is much more than a cornerstone of international law: It is a guide to navigate the deeply divided world, a set of values that everyone can live by and ultimately a force of good. And yet, we know that "All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights" represents a promise not yet fulfilled – for 2SLGBTQ2+ people across the world and for everyone experiencing the suffocating impact on their lives of diverse layers of inequalities. This year's IDAHBT theme is a call for unity: Only through solidarity for each other will we create a world without injustice, where no one is left behind.” ❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🤎🖤🤍🩷🩵 #InternationalDayAgainstHomophobiaAndTransphobia #ForeverProud #ForeverProgressing #2SLGBTQ #Equality #Freedom #Justice #IDAHBT

Hugely important step forward for the LGBTQ+ community in Hong Kong with this Court of Final Appeal decision that the failure of the government to provide alternative means of recognising same-sex partnerships is a violation of the constitutional right to privacy. Progress towards equity and equality for same sex partnerships has so far been driven by our fantastic courts and the tireless efforts of brave and dedicated advocates. **** “By a majority, as indicated in paragraph 214 above and as provided below, subject to receiving written submissions from the parties (whereupon the following Declaration and accompanying Direction may be modified or confirmed) [the Court]: (i) Declares that, the Government is in violation of its positive obligation under Article 14 of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights to establish an alternative framework for legal recognition of same-sex partnerships (such as registered civil partnerships or civil unions) and to provide for appropriate rights and obligations attendant on such recognition with a view to ensuring effective compliance with the aforesaid obligation. (ii) Directs that operation of the abovementioned Declaration be suspended for a period of two years from the date of the final Order to be made after receipt of the parties’ written submissions, to afford the Government time to comply with its aforesaid obligation.” **** Now for our Government to create the legislative framework. #lgbtqrights #hongkong #progress

Big tech is exploiting the LGBTQIA+ community to avoid regulations, causing serious damage. Companies claim they are attempting to make their platforms safer. Still, evidence suggests their hyper-targeted algorithmic processes increase users' vulnerability to mental health issues like anxiety, despair, eating disorders, and suicide ideation. Among LGBTQIA+ adolescents, 24% were more likely than non-LGBTQIA+ youth to be recommended dieting or pro-eating disorder content whenever they used the platform. 56% of LGBTQIA+ kids and 32% of non-LGBTQIA+ youth reported experiencing cyberbullying at some point. These businesses aren't driven to improve; they're rewarded for keeping the issue under wraps. Instagram's pro-eating disorder material generates about $230 million in revenue annually. The Kids Online Safety Act would force Big Tech to stop engaging in unethical commercial activities.
